Interpretation: Perfect identification of all study identifiers with correct author names and publication years.
All study countries were correctly identified without any discrepancies.
Some terminology variations noted; "Longitudinal cohort" and "Prospective observational" were used instead of the standardized "Prospective cohort study" in three cases.
Three discrepancies identified; primarily due to reporting different sample subsets (e.g.; complete cases vs. full imputed sample; or analysis sample vs. baseline sample).
Two studies had missing values where the ground truth contained numeric data; remaining values matched within tolerance.
Standard errors were frequently reported as NA in the extracted data; even when values were available in the original papers; this represents systematic under-extraction.
Three studies had missing or incomplete age range information; however; when reported; the structural format was appropriately captured.
Several discrepancies observed; including one value reversal (likely male/female confusion); approximate values instead of precise figures; and missing data.
All screen equipment types were correctly identified across studies; minor formatting variations did not affect content accuracy.
Exposure definitions were comprehensively captured with appropriate semantic detail across all nine studies.
One study misclassified as "categorical" when the ground truth specified "gender-specific" exposure categorization.
All depression assessment instruments were correctly identified; with appropriate abbreviations and full names.
Perfect distinction between screening-scale and clinical-diagnosis outcome types across all studies.
Three discrepancies noted; "Unclear" was used in two cases where ground truth specified definitive values; and one "Yes" was misclassified as "No".
Follow-up durations were correctly captured; including complex structures with split follow-up periods or ranges.
Most key covariates were captured across studies; some minor omissions and additions observed; but core adjustment variables were generally present.
Four studies were misclassified as "Adjusted" when the ground truth indicated "Both" (adjusted and unadjusted estimates available); suggests systematic under-recognition of unadjusted estimates.

The LLM extraction demonstrated strong performance on core identifiers; outcome measures; and exposure-related variables; but showed systematic weaknesses in extracting statistical parameters (Age_SE); sample size disambiguation; and recognizing when both adjusted and unadjusted estimates were reported.
